user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport:
```c
void UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport(const char *SegmentName, const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char ReportBuffer[144];

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%-22s ABORT::%-4u  WARN::%-4u  FLOW::%-4u  DEBUG::%-4u  N/A::%-4u",
             "",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FLOW],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NA]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_INFO, ReportBuffer);

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%02u %-20s TOTAL::%-4u  PASS::%-4u  FAIL::%-4u  MIR::%-4u  TSF::%-4u  TTF::%-4u",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount, SegmentName, (unsigned int)TestCounters->TotalTestCases,
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END, ReportBuffer);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport:
void UT_BSP_DoText(uint8 MessageType, const char *OutputMessage)
{
    char   Buffer[16];
    size_t MsgLen;
    uint32 TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
    uint32 MsgEnabled   = BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity >> MessageType;

    if (MsgEnabled & 1)
    {
        UT_BSP_Lock();

        /* Determine if the message type warrants special treatment (color/highlight/etc). */
        switch (MessageType)
        {
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_BLUE;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN:
                OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1); /* add a bit of extra whitespace between tests */
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            default:
                break;
        }

        if (MsgEnabled <= 1)
        {
            TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
        }

        snprintf(Buffer, sizeof(Buffer), "[%5s]", UtAssert_GetCaseTypeAbbrev(MessageType));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(TermModeBits);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Buffer, strlen(Buffer));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(" ", 1);
        MsgLen = strlen(OutputMessage);
        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(OutputMessage, MsgLen);
        if (MsgLen == 0 || OutputMessage[MsgLen - 1] != '\n')
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1);
        }

        UT_BSP_Unlock();
    }

    /*
     * If any ABORT (major failure) message is thrown,
     * then call a BSP-provided routine to stop the test and possibly dump a core
     */
    if (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT)
    {
        OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl();
    }
}
...
void OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl(void)
{
    abort();
}
...
typedef struct
{
    uint32 TestSegmentCount;
    uint32 TotalTestCases;
    uint32 CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX];
} UtAssert_TestCounter_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that are demonstrably unreachable in the supplied code. Rationale:

- UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport: the function executes two snprintf calls followed by two UT_BSP_DoText calls in sequence; there are no early returns, goto statements, infinite loops, or other constructs that would make any of these statements impossible to reach at runtime.

- UT_BSP_DoText: the large output block is conditional on (MsgEnabled & 1) and therefore is not intrinsically unreachable — its execution depends on the runtime value of BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity and MessageType. The final check if (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT) calls OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl(), which invokes abort(), a non-returning runtime action; however this call is conditional and there is no code after it within the function that would become unreachable as a result. Thus there is no unreachable code fragment inside UT_BSP_DoText itself.

- OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl simply calls abort(); this function is reachable and intentionally non-returning when invoked. There is no code after its call in the same function that would be rendered unreachable.

Notes on items that might superficially look suspicious but are not unreachable:
- The first snprintf in UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport passes an empty string for the %-22s field while SegmentName is used in the second snprintf. This is a logic/format issue (unused argument in the first report line) but it does not create unreachable code.

- Potential unreachable switch cases or duplicate enum values cannot be assessed here because the enum/constant definitions for the UTASSERT_CASETYPE_* values were not provided. If any two case labels are defined to the same integral value, one case could be unreachable; however there is no evidence of that in the supplied code fragments.

Given the provided code and symbol definitions, there are no definite instances of unreachable code to report for MISRA C Rule 2.1.
